awd_titl_txt: Rapid Analytical Device for the Performance of Construction Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a device to predict the performance of key construction materials in a matter of few minutes. Construction materials and chemicals are required to undergo a quality control process via standardized specifications and performance tests. Globally, there is a strong push for decarbonizing energy-intensive industries, such as cement production, which accounts for 6-8% of global carbon emissions. In the short term, the cement industry is looking to reduce its carbon footprint by partially replacing cement with sustainable supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs). The replacement of cement with low-carbon SCMs is estimated to be able to result in CO2 savings of up to 30 percent. One of the barriers faced by the industry is the highly variable quality of these low-carbon SCMs and the lack of real-time methods for quality control. Quality control managers and cement kiln supervisors at cement plants across the world are looking for reliable, online quality control tools.  The proposed technology may enable better quality control for newer SCMs, which may facilitate their application in the cement industry. In addition, this may open pathways for rapid, online quality control of low carbon building materials.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a rapid analytics device for real-time quality control of sustainable supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs).  Newer materials proposed to replace cement in order to speed up the decarbonization of the concrete sector are reliant on traditional, time- and labor-intensive quality control tests that may take up to 7 days. This proposed technology is based on previous research on the chemistry of SCMs, and combines fundamental principles of low-cost material characterization and analysis.  The analysis obtained from various natural and commercial SCMs using the proposed technology are consistent with the performance measured using current standard methods.  In addition, the proposed technology reduced the performance prediction time from days to minutes, which may enable real-time characterization in the production line. Further, this device may have an economic advantage over current practices as it utilizes low-cost detection equipment to allow automatic operation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Cement is one of the most consumed construction materials in the world. However, its production accounts for approximately 8% of global carbon emissions. Newer materials such as fly ash and calcined clays have become popular to address the sustainability challenges associated with cement production. However, these materials are highly variable in terms of their composition, and quality control for them is a time-consuming process, taking up to 7 days to fully assess performance. In 2022, we began developing a method to reduce the quality control time for cementitious materials. We created a technology that can assess the performance of construction materials in 5 minutes, which is 1,400 times faster than the conventional method that takes 7 days. To assess the market demand for our method, we participated in the NSF I-Corps program in 2023.

Through the NSF I-Corps program, we engaged in extensive customer discovery to understand the real-world challenges faced by quality control engineers, researchers, and manufacturers. We conducted over 100 interviews with industry stakeholders, including cement producers, ready-mix concrete suppliers, and academic researchers. These conversations helped us validate the demand for a rapid, accurate, and cost-effective testing method for alternative cementitious materials.

There are several key outcomes from the project. First, we successfully refined our value proposition through multiple iterations and extensive customer feedback. Leveraging insights from the NSF I-Corps program, we developed a comprehensive business model canvas that identified our target customers, beachhead market, revenue streams, and growth strategy. Initially, our focus was solely on cement producers. However, through customer discovery, we realized that they should serve as the starting point rather than the sole target. Our primary market should be the end users, such as ready-mix concrete plants, which number in the thousands and represent a significantly larger opportunity. As a result, our go-to-market strategy is to begin with influential cement producers to establish credibility and then expand downstream to reach ready-mix plants, thereby scaling our business. Moreover, the research labs are also potential customers, as our technology is low-cost, fast, and will benefit researchers. By the end of the project, we had a clear roadmap for bringing our device to market and sustaining it in the long term.

One of the most valuable insights was recognizing that a subscription-based model would be the most effective approach for industry adoption. This model allows us to deliver regular updates and improvements to users based on their evolving needs. We also identified key partners, including original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), who will support the development and scaling of our prototype. Additionally, cement and clay plant manufacturers have emerged as valuable potential partners, as our device can be integrated and sold alongside their production systems, enhancing their quality control capabilities and expanding our market reach.

Moreover, through customer discovery, we improved and validated our methodology using industrial cementitious materials samples provided by partners. This allowed us to evaluate our device’s performance under variable samples and make necessary refinements. As a result, we built strong relationships with our beachhead customers. We have secured our first customer, received multiple letters of support and commitment from stakeholders, and are well-positioned for the next stage of commercialization.

 


Last Modified: 04/05/2025
Modified by: Nishant Garg
